content.description: Crack and ledge system going up the NW corner of the Doorway. Potential descent route if you didn't take a rope up.
content.location: See picture. This is route #1 in the 3rd edition of the DL guidebook by Swartling and Meyer.

content.description: Perhaps the best offwidth at Devil's Lake.  Impossible Crack is the very obvious line on the lefthand pillar of Devil's Doorway when viewed from the East.  Start up by making a few face moves to gain the perfect (#2 Camalot) handcrack in the two-foot roof.  Surmount the roof and climb offwidth to top, using a few small face holds on the right.  Do your best not to stand on any of the ledges that are so close and beckoning...
content.protection: Nuts/tricams, to a #2 C4 (or two), to a #4 C4, and finally a #5 C4 (or two).
content.location: On Devil's Doorway proper.  Easily noticed as the large crack just left of the doorway when viewed from the East.

content.protection: Free solo. There's an eyebolt at the top of the Doorway.
content.location: The doorway of "Devil's Doorway". Route #3 in picture for Romper.

content.description: "A fall from this knife-edged crack can be messy. This climb follows a thin crack near the northwest edge of the south pillar of the Doorway. Begin on a bench 6 ft. above the ground." (1970 Climbers and Hikers Guide)
content.protection: A couple of half inch nuts or cams.
content.location: On the west side of the Doorway's south pillar.  You can mount the initial ledge either from the south or the west.

content.description: The most easily identified formation in the Park.  There are 4-5 good routes to the top, and a massive eye-bolt at the top for your descent.
